title: 'Superforecasting' Author -- Don't Dismiss Analysts Over Big Jobs Miss
text:
'Superforecasting' Author -- Don't Dismiss Analysts Over Big Jobs Miss Written by: Gregg Greenberg 10/02/15 - 2:39 PM EDT 
NEW YORK (TheStreet) -- The U.S. economy added 142,000 jobs in September, far fewer than the 200,000 predicted by Wall Street's experts. While it's a glaring miss, Philip Tetlock, co-author of Superforecasting and co-leader of the Good Judgment Project, said the investment banks need not dismiss all their economists yet. 
"The only way we can identify superforecasters is on the basis of hundreds of judgments they make over extended periods of time," said Tetlock. "That's how you sort out the superforecasters from the not-so-good forecasters." 
The Good Judgment Project is a multi-year forecasting study that Tetlock co-leads with his wife, Barbara Mellers. The project studies tens of thousands of ordinary volunteers -- including a Brooklyn filmmaker, a retired pipe installer and a former ballroom dancer -- who are asked to forecast global events. Among them, some are far better than average at predicting the direction of events. Dubbed " superforecasters " by Tetlock, they do not rely on powerful computers or mathematical algorithms, but that smaller group in the aggregate continues to make better predictions than their benchmarks and intelligence analysts. "Superforecasters make a major effort to distinguish as many degrees of doubt as the problem permits," said Tetlock. "They realize they are playing a game of odds, it's a long-term game, and you don't conclude that someone is a superforecaster based on one hit." 
According to Tetlock, the key to becoming a better forecaster, if not a super one, is the same as any other endeavor: Practice, practice, practice. 
"If you don't take seriously the proposition that probability estimation is a skill that can be cultivated and is worth cultivating, then you are not going to get better at it," said Tetlock. 
Superforecasting has its limitations, of course. And making a short term score either in the stock market or at the roulette table in Las Vegas is one of them. One of the keys to being a superforecaster, said Tetlock, is knowing these limitations. 
"You have to pick your battles wisely," said Tetlock. "Superforecasters focus on problems where analytical effort pays off and they recognize that there are some categories of problems where there is so much irreducible uncertainty, effort is not going to pay off, so they don't invest very much."
